bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Sidney Wallach, March 13, 1950

div1.p: Hench suggests a Reed memorial which would have long-range value to the public rather than a short-term publicity campaign. He discusses Camp Lazear and Building No. 1, and his efforts to have this site memorialized. Hench informs Wallach of the work of the Walter Reed Memorial Association, and other attempts to publicize Reed's work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Sidney Wallach, March 13, 1950
div1.opener:
March 13, 1950
Mr. Sidney Wallach
381 Fourth Avenue
New York 16, New York
My dear Mr. Wallach:
div1.p:
I have been away from the Clinic for awhile and have your letter
of February 21 in which you tell me of your efforts to bring to the attention
of the public the work of Walter Reed during the coming year or two. I am
heartily in favor of such a venture, however I wondered if a memorial to Walter
Reed and his colleagues involving as much as $350,000 should concern only a
sort of publicity campaign. Wouldn't it be much better to provide a more
lasting and suitable memorial which would have a long-range value to the public?
Please do not misunderstand me. I am most heartily in favor of anything that
can be done to honor the name of Dr. Walter Reed and his colleagues. I have
for many years made the story of their work an intensely interesting hobby and
I propose as soon as time permits to write a monograph on the subject.

There is one item which I think would be looked upon with favor by
several of those concerned with the conquest of yellow fever. A few years
ago Mr. John Moran (one of Walter Reed's first volunteers) and I rediscovered Camp
Lazear where Reed did his work and found still standing, but in pretty rickety
condition, the little Building No. 1 which was so crucial to the experiments.
I tried to raise some money in this country and to get the Cuban Government
to help memorialize the place. My plans involved an expenditure of perhaps
$50,000 to restore the little building and build over and around it a small
public health center for the town of Quemados de Marianao where the building
now stands. My plans were approved heartily by the Cuban Government.I had
an interview with a number of prominent men two or three years ago, including
the Vice-President and they actually put through a bill authorizing an initial
expenditure of $50,000 to preserve the little building. I constructed rough
plans of a little memorial park etc., and the bill was passed by the Cuban
legislature and I have a newspaper clipping indicating this. However that
regime almost immediately went out of office and all such financial expendi-
tures fall by the wayside when a new regime comes in.

I have visited Cuba several times in behalf of this little project.
I know that the Surgeon General of the U. S. Army is interested in it and on
one occasion several years ago Mr. Johnson, Secretary of Defense, was interested
in it as he happened to be in Rochester and heard me give a talk. My own hope
would be that part of your proposed bill would involve an expenditure of between
$50,000 and $100,000 to build this little memorial and present this little health
unit to the Cuban Government in honor of Reed and his colleagues.

This involves, of course, the controversy that is still raging in Cuba
in some less intelligent sources as to the credit for the conquest of yellow
fever. A small but very vocal minority think that Reed and the Americans
robbed Finlay of his just fame. That is decidedly not true and responsible
men with whom I have talked have no patience with their vocal brethrem. I
do not believe that there would be any real difficulty if American money
was forthcoming for this project. I think the only reason that the Cubans
haven't done it is their congenital attitude of manana and the fact that
Cuban money has a habit of coming and going in various ways.

Mr. Wallach, I do not set myself up to decide what shall be the best
method of memorializing Walter Reed and his colleagues. In my own little way
I have tried to do it by writing two or three little articles and I had planned
to write another one to appear this year, the 50th anniversary. However Fate
has caught me up in my own medical work so that I will probably not be able
to do this as I am working intensively on another project that cannot wait. I
tried to interest Mr. Steven Spencer, one of the editors of the Saturday Evening
Post, to write an article on the subject and I offered him several points that
I thought would bring the story up to date; however they ran a story in the
Saturday Evening Post on Moran, several years back, and the Chief Editor turned
down Mr. Spencer's idea, the latter having been willing to write the article. I
next contacted Mr. Robert Potter, a science writer now connected with the New
York Academy of Medicine but he is so involved with his own work, a new job,
that he cannot do it. I am about to write to two or three other science
writers to see if they would do it. I do think that such an article should
appear this year.

Recently I have had some telephonic communications with someone in
the State Department who has been helping with the preliminary plans of the
radio program “We, the People” which intends to put on a story and proposes
to bring up one or two of the surviving volunteers to lend the personal touch
to the story.

Are you aware that shortly a small plaque will be placed outside of an
old building which in 1902 was an Army hospital in which Walter Reed died. This
plaque has been placed through the efforts of the Walter Reed Memorial Associa-
tion and the Surgeon General of the U. S. Army.

It seems to me that all of these things could be tied to one project
and undoubtedly other procedures could be added to make the memorial more ef-
fective. I would be interested in your further comments.

I am sending by separate post some reprints which may interest you.
It gives a photograph of the little shack and if you are interested in con-
sidering the memorializing of this shack, I can later send you photographic
copies of my plans and perhaps we might have a conference sometime with the
Surgeon General. I have no doubt that with the help of the Surgeon General
and the Secretary of Defense something can be done along this line. My
great regret is that I cannot spend the necessary time on doing this.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
cc: General Reed, Blossom Reed, General Kean, General Truby, Colonel Siler
